Authors:
Hong Chang Lim, Suh Nih Tan, Sing Tung Teng, Nina Lundholm,
Emma Orive, Helena David, Sonia Quijano-Scheggia, Stephen S. Bates, Po
Teen Lim, Chui Pin Leaw
Title:
Species delineation in the marine diatom Pseudo-nitzschia
(Bacillariophyceae) using cox1, LSU and ITS2 rDNAs sequences: a
perspective in character evolution
Keywords:
Pseudo-nitzschia; cox1; phylogeny; character evolution;
molecular markers
Abstract:
Analyses of the mitochondrial cox1 and nuclear-encoded
large subunit (LSU) and the second transcribed spacer (ITS2) rDNAs
sequences of Pseudo-nitzschia revealed that the P. pseudodelicatissima
complex can be phylogenetically grouped into three distinct clades
(Groups IÂ–III), while the P. delicatissima complex forms another distinct
clade (Group IV) in both the LSU and ITS2 phylogenetic trees. It was
elucidated that a dense taxon sampling, selection of appropriate target
genes, outgroup selection and alignment strategies influence the
phylogenetic accuracy. Based on the genetic divergence, ITS2 yielded the
higher genetic distance, followed by cox1 and LSU. The morphological
characters available for Pseudo-nitzschia, although limited in number,
were in agreement with the phylogenies when mapped onto the ITS2 trees.
Information on the presence or absence of a central nodule and changes
in the number of rows of poroids revealed the evolution of the recently
diverged species. The morphologically based species complexes showed
evolutionary relevance in agreement with ITS2 sequence-structure
inferred molecular phylogeny. The taxonomic status of P. cuspidata and
P. pseudodelicatissima requires further elucidation.
